content.body: not as noticeable as in ie where the whole address bar is red and there's a red warning box next to the address bar
Hmm, true.  Looks neater, though.
also not as noticeable as having to click through a few dialogs.
Yes, I should really have said "cure" or something.
"cute"
It's rather less noticeable than some browsers' warnings.
Which is fair enough, since 99.8% of the time, it will just be a site with a bad cert and not someone evil.
Freaking out just encourages users to ignore security warnings, since they rightfully conclude that browser implementers are paranoid.
Which they all seem to be, without exception.  I haven't ever seen a sane response from a browser to something like a bad SSL certificate.
An appropriate response when visiting a new site would probably be a prominent visual cue in the URL bar, but with no extra screen to click through unless you try to submit a form or something.
is that what chrome does?
No, Chrome gives a moderately scary page you have to click through.
They let you do it in one click, but it's still overkill if you're visiting some random wiki or whatever.
https://circumflex.us/wiki/ is not a security threat.
Yeah, it would be nice if you could just fail on a bad cert, but in practice they're almost all non-malicious, so let's not try to misrepresent reality to users, shall we?
There's some thing going on in public-webapps where they want to allow sites to force SSL only, and that's great.
SSL only with hard failure on cert errors, obviously.
a visual cue is easily missed by users, so it'd be pretty bad in the 0.2% cases where the site is evil and steals all your money (or whatever)
zcorpan, users will be trained by then to automatically click the scary dialogs though
the dialogs do more bad than good. Since the majority of the time the user will ignore them, they'll do it for the actual bad case too
zcorpan, 1) You could have the page only pop up on form submissions.  2) Overstating severity in almost all cases will cause users to just ignore you in the long term, it's never the right answer.
what if the evil site has a form but the script prevents submission and steals login credentials?
Then I guess you're screwed.  See (2).  Of course, you can add other heuristics too, like give scary errors only if the user has previously visited the site with a valid SSL certificate.
That will help prevent obvious MITM against amazon.com or such.
that's a good option
Also, you could pop up the warning as soon as the user starts typing in a form.
The point is, though, just popping up Yet Another Warning to click through isn't a good option at all.  At least AFAIK.  Has anyone done usability research on this?
you could trick the user to think he's typing in a form but there's actually no form so the browser can't know when to pop up the warning
Yes, then you're screwed, as I said.
Perhaps the solution is that everyone should stop using SSL, unless they're something serious like a bank

It reminds me of an article I read a while back by some guy.  He remarked that as a Windows GUI user, he was trained to just ignore all warnings, because he figured they wouldn't let him do anything really unsafe.  Then he tried Linux for a while.  After a while, for some reason he wanted to run fsck on a mounted filesystem, or such.  It said "WARNING, this filesystem seems to be mounted, running fsck will probably destroy all your data.  Are
you sure?"  He said yes and lost all his data, and from then on learned that Linux command line utilities actually give accurate warnings.
to avoid the situation where broken certificates on random mailing lists and bugzillas you find when searching on Google result in you learning to ignore broken certificates

Except that actually he didn't, because this article was about how he tried out btrfs as his root filesystem even though it was clearly marked as usable only for development, and he found out it wasn't usable.
Philip`, a broken cert is actually more secure than no cert.  It doesn't prevent an active attacker, but it prevents passive sniffing.
Also, if you whitelist it the first time, you'll be informed again if it changes.
is partially responsible for proliferation of insecure certificates, since he set up a self-signed HTTPS thing on his server primarily so that SVN clients could get safely through proxies
Philip`: your certificate isn't insecure though, right?
He said it's self-signed.
It just doesn't prove your identify
Well, the same is true for any cert, typically.
true
Also also, in practice, users will often visit SSL-secured sites via ordinary HTTP (e.g., typing "amazon.com" into URL bar), so you can spoof some percentage even without raising SSL warnings.
doublec: I guess it encrypts securely, assuming the command-line string I copied from a random website is set up correctly
haha, good point
but it's self-signed, it's not set up with the same domain name it's being used on, and I won't notice or care enough to update it once it reaches the expiry date
and that you didn't use a version of an os with a bad openssl library

Proposed UI #2: Flat-out refuse SSL access with a bad cert to a manually-maintained list of high-profile e-commerce sites, with no opt-out.  For other sites, on the first visit have a non-blocking warning in the top, saying something like "This site may not be secure; don't submit sensitive information to it. [More Info] [X]"
Your list can safely include any large e-commerce site, I'd hope, so it can be pretty large.
I've been unable to instruct myself or people who turn to me for advice how to tell apart innocent cert expiration and an attack
seems cost-effective to always assume innocent expiration
Check the hash on the root CA and manually compare it to the correct hash obtained by Googling.
Expiration or just misconfiguration.
SSL is a PITA to configure right.
Especially if you have multiple hosts on the same machine.
There was a time when https://google.com would return a cert error.
I don't know what hash "the hash" is
There you go: https://amazon.com/
Hmm, does Chrome expose cert details anywhere?
as far as I'm aware, I've never been MITM'ed but I've seen a zillion cert failures
just clicking through is rational economics
Yes, precisely.  And by misrepresenting this basic fact, all the major browsers are contributing to user contempt for browser warnings.
I've had similar experiences with Chrome's malware-site-blacklist.
(I have, as a matter of principle, spent non-trivial time double-checking failures, though)
It repeatedly brought up a giant scary red page on my site because someone hotlinked an image hosted on a blacklisted domain.
http://hsivonen.iki.fi/extended-uncertainty/

wonders if a more usable system for preventing realistic attacks is to simply proxy all traffic through a trusted server with a hard-coded properly-maintained certificate, rather than relying on a zillion sites to each implement it themselves
In Firefox, Page Info -> Security -> View Certificate -> Details, I think "Subject's Public Key" for the highest-level certificate is what's important.
But I'm not sure.
Philip`, how would those sites authenticate to the server?
since that'd at least work for the situation where you're connecting through an untrusted wireless network
AryehGregor: They wouldn't
It's unlikely anyone will MITM between the proxy server and the web site
Hmm.
You could hack a router, it's not necessarily very hard.
But harder than setting up a free wireless access point, yes.
I would really like to see some statistics on how often MITM attacks actually occur, and what users do in the face of different types of error pages.
I suspect that MITM attacks are *vanishingly* rare in practice.
Like say less than 1 in 10,000 cert errors.
Or even less.  I've never even *heard* of an actual MITM attack.
I mean, on SSL on the public web etc.
The sort we're talking about, like someone steals your bank password.
You can download easy-to-use tools to break into wireless networks and capture traffic, and as far as I'm aware there's nothing quite so trivial for breaking into remote internet routers
Yes, it would be harder.
MITMing doesn't need to be made impossible, it just needs to be made hard enough that people won't attack that way and will use phishing or trojans or whatever
(which I presume is what they already do)
mpilgrim: in the forms chapter where you talk about type=email, it seems you've forgotten about form validation
Ultimately it should be made impossible if we can.  Making it unattractive is a good start, though.
mpilgrim: opera won't submit the form if the user types in an invalid email address
I don't think routing everything through a central server is a practical solution, though.
AryehGregor: Have lots of decentralised servers :-)
They just need to be connected to infrastructure that's reasonably well maintained and not entirely trivial to break into
earlier opera versions also supported autofilling type=email with addresses from the address book, but that was removed to prevent phishing the user's address book with clever tricks, iirc
zcorpan: :-(
zcorpan: has type=url autocompletion been removed, too?
no
i guess it could be used to find out which bank the user uses
You can already do that by looking at the link color.
but then you need to guess the url
with type=url you can have a fun game that's controlled with up and down keys and enter
Just try the URLs of every major bank.  You can do lots per second, with no user interaction.
yeah
Have you seen those cool demos where you just visit a web page and let it run for a while and it gives you a square with the favicons of all the sites you visit?
no
anyway, bed time
AryehGregor: do you have a link for that favicon demo?
Sadly, no.
Is anyone other than Gecko planning on switching to HTML5 parsing anytime soon?

Should crossOriginIframe.contentDocument.foobar throw SECURITY_ERR?
Yes, because everything goes to the getter
i almost a SECURITY_ERR once
Hixie: hmm, so should the ApplicationCache interface object be accessible to a shared worker, but not a dedicated worker?
currently yes
Hixie: As far as I can tell, crossOriginIframe.contentDocument[1] shouldn't throw SECURITY_ERR. Is that intended?
off-hand, no idea whatsoever
What about crossOriginIframe.contentDocument.foobar?
For that I can read the spec either way as to whether it can throw.
i do not feel comfortable answering security-level questions without several hours of getting familiar with the subject matter again :-)
So, per HTML 5, everything in crossOriginIframe.contentDocument that is in Document should throw.
This only happens in IE on the real web.
At least in a simple case like http://software.hixie.ch/utilities/js/live-dom-viewer/saved/329
what do other UAs do?
Everything else gives the element
i.e., HTMLHtmlElement
safari seems to be showing another document than the one returned through the dom
Yet in most cases all browsers throw
What's going on with that simple case?
timing maybe?
yes, timing
i bet that's the about:blank page
Ah
before it loads example.com
Right
Duh, that makes sense
man you're making me work on stuff
The fact that iframe.contentDocument should throw is implicit from the fact that it is accessing a member of a Window object?

Is hgroup a block level element?
formatBlock candidate.
but, hehe, i don't think says anythin aabout being a block element , sorry
formatBlock candidate means "could be block soon, yo."
JonathanNeal: Since it wraps block-level elements, I'm going with "yes".
"formatBlock candidate" means you can use it as the second argument to the "formatBlock" command, which wraps something in whatever you give as the second argument.
So that lends itself to the "hgroup is a block" theory as well.
JonathanNeal: What do you mean by "block level element"?
Philip`: Default styles, in the CSS sense.
TabAtkins, I agree.
If you care about default styles, look in the default styles section of the spec
